speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But perhaps we should flesh this out a little bit already with the first point we make here in the paper about the performance competence distinction, which is a nice way to bring about both anthropomorphism and anthropocentrism regarding
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this distinction is a very classic distinction in linguistics and cognitive science, and it has already been applied to AI systems in the neural networks productively, like Chas Parsons.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's nothing really new here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the distinction comes from Noam Chomsky originally, and the idea is that performance pertains to the external behavior of a system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in a particular domain and competence is the kind of set of underlying knowledge and computations or mechanisms that enable the system to achieve that behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And a family observation in linguistics and cognitive science is that there is a double association between performance and competence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you take, for example, language,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I might, during this very podcast, make some grammatical mistakes or some other mistakes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In fact, I've already misspoken a few times, I think, and repeated myself.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I've made performance errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this does not entail necessarily, hopefully, that I'm an incompetent language user and that I don't have the underlying linguistic competence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's a well-recognized dissociation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You can be competent and yet make some errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the reason for that is that there might be some additional factors that are unrelated to the underlying competence that might impede
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: on my performance so for example i might be distracted when i speak or there might be other effects on my speaking performance that don't actually originate from a lack of competence but just impede on my on the the the idealized expression external manifestation of my competence and this is why i speak but it's also why we recognize that you can have good uh performance without confidence
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we give here an example of a student cheating on a test or memorizing test answers by brute forcing the test into a slightly more, I guess, gray area.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But at least in the cheating case, a student can ace a test without being competent at whatever the test is actually testing for.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: um and it's also well acknowledged in cognitive science that there can be instances like this throughout um you know um like that can be manifested certain experimental settings where the test subject is right
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: where namely it's doing well, it's exhibiting good performance, and then we realize the underlying reason for the good performance is that there was perhaps some heuristic that the experimenters or the scientists hadn't thought about that could account for this good performance, but doesn't actually amount to whatever competence they were setting out to test.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we start by saying, well, this is what we recognize.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is the world association that is supplied to humans across the board.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You can have performance without competence, good performance without competence, and you can have bad performance despite competence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, when it comes to LLMs, the point we make, I'm just going to scroll as we go, we have some figures to share later, but the point we make is that generally people stress the dissociation, apply the distinction to LLMs, but stress dissociation only in one direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: unlike in the case of human where it's bi-directional.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so what people do generally is they say, well, other labs famously, you know, if you look at the GPT-4 technical report and various other, any report about a new state of the art other lab, they are getting really, really good at a number of tests and about benchmarks and even human examinations, human exams, the bar exam, medical exams, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So they can create really good performance tests that we tend to think are really difficult tests that one can only pass, at least a human could only pass, if they have a really significant amount of competency.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the point that is often made when it comes to LLMs is be careful, slow down, and try to find out why the model is doing well on that test, because there are various reasons why it could do well that do not actually indicate that the model has the underlying competence that the test was designed for when it comes to humans.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So one big concern, for example, is data contamination, where very large language models train on Internet-scale data.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: can easily be trained on some test items from common benchmarks that leak into the training data such that they can then do really well on the benchmark just because they've essentially memorized test items.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And there are other more subtle reasons why performance could be very good for the wrong reasons.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's very well recognized.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And a lot of the people who push
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: bias when it comes to LLM.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Make that point.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Be careful.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Do not take on an orthomorphic attitude to the systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The reason why they do well is not because they have human-like intelligence or human-like current capacities, but it's for these trivial, contingent, or otherwise irrelevant reasons that account for the good performance.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, when it comes to the other dissociation or the dissociation in the other direction,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: their people are very reluctant to apply to LLMs.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we think it's because essentially people think in a human case, you can make sense of the idea that the human could do badly on a test or corporate could perform badly on a task.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and yet have the competence that you're trying to test, but there might be some auxiliary factors, such as working memory limitations, attention deficits, et cetera, that could impede on the performance.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A lot of people don't think that there is an analogous mechanism at play, where there could be some kind of auxiliary factor that impedes on performance.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Performance is what you get.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What you see is what you get.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so the performance is a direct manifestation
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: what the system is computing and if you have performance errors, that can only be explained by the lack of competence because there is no additional independent factor or module that could impede on the performance.

text: In comparative cognition, one famous behavioral experiment is the mirror test for self-recognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the question is, roughly, do non-human animals have something like a concept of self?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the strategy is to put some sort of mark on their body.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In the original experiments, it was a red dot on the forehead of maybe a monkey or a bird or whatever.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then you put that animal in front of a mirror and see if it makes any attempt to get rid of the mark.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if it does make an attempt to get rid of the mark, that shows that it recognizes that the image in the mirror is an image of itself and otherwise not.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's a cool way to get at a really difficult and abstract question about the mind of a non-human animal.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But it presumes or it assumes that animals will care about the fact that they have a red dot on their forehead, that they will be bothered by that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and be motivated to get rid of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if that assumption is wrong, then they might fail the mirror test for self-recognition for reasons that have little to do with the presence or absence of a capacity for self-recognition.

text: And so something similar to that is going on, we say, in large language models.

text: So the first example that we give is to do with task demands.

text: So it's a pretty natural idea that whenever you set up a behavioral task, there will be demands associated with that task.

text: that are not directly related to the capacity that you're trying to test.

okay um so the the third type of type one uh anthropocentric uh bias that we talk about is mechanistic interference and so um this comes from the mechanistic interpretability work and the basic idea is that because um large language models are capable of in context learning they can learn different strategies
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: for solving a different particular type of problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the strategy that they implement at a given time can be different.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you can talk about this in terms of virtual circuits that are formed inside the language model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's some interesting work from Neil Nanda and others showing that in some circumstances, these two circuits can compete with one another.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: a certain level of uh or after a certain amount of training you get one circuit operative after a bit more training you have two different circuits um but they're uh the first circuit is still sort of dominant and um then after additional training the model um
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: converges on the second circuit.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the first one slowly gets sort of, it sort of ceases to influence the internal operations of the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it's only once you reach that third phase at which the
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: benefits of the second circuit with respect to the first become visible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you can you can show using decoding work that the second circuit is there before you can show behaviorally that the second circuit yields better performance accuracy on the task.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I suppose there's a combination of two ideas here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One is that there are different strategies a model can implement for solving a problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We can detect those strategies internally using decoding methods.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So three ideas.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the third is
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: a good strategy can be present in some sense in the model before it has had the chance to influence behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so this is just another way that the link between performance and competence is shown to be more complicated than it might seem at first.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Raf can certainly explain that.

text: And just to clarify one thing, circuits are just ways to think about the causal structure of a neural network.

text: And they're essentially computational subgraphs of the network that have a specific function.

text: And you can think
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: of computations um it's a part of what people are interested in in this mechanistic interpretability literature that we build on people like neil meldak chris ola and others is reverse engineering these circuits that in deep neural networks and large language models appear to implement certain well-defined algorithms in some cases at least and the emerging picture that we build on here is that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: there is a lot of redundancy built into neural networks as they learn to perform a task or optimize a function that, in many cases, translates into redundant circuits that relate to the same task, the same kinds of
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the same kinds of input-output mappings, and these circuits might be somewhat identical circuits that are just redundant, or they might be different algorithms just to do a similar thing, and different strategies to solve some problem elsewhere.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Maybe one will be a bit more approximative, and the other one a bit more exact, more computationally intensive.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's where you can have some interference, where one
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: or do some competition where one circuit takes over another such that the other becomes kind of, you know, it's there, it's latent in the system, but it doesn't get a chance to influence behavior on a specific input.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you can get a performance error for that reason.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And these can combine with the other things we mentioned here.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So, so, so just want to chat to some of the questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the question is,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: how is the notion of a capacity changing when we have such different systems that seem to have intelligent behavior?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yeah, and it's so dependent upon potentially initially unintuitive ways of interacting.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So how can we understand the reliability and the performance and the capacity of a model
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: other than, for example, by exhaustively inputting prompts, which can't really happen, what could we really say or know?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And or just how do you feel that this work reenters into the ways that people practically are using the models?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's a very interesting question.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the first part of the question is, I think
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Part of the background assumption from this paper that I've explicitly defended in other work is that behavioral evidence is simply not sufficient in most cases to arbitrate disputes about capacities of algorithms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When it comes to human cognition,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We do have to rely a lot on psychological experiments that are ultimately behavioral.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we do also rely on self-reports a little more than we can when it comes to LLMs because we, despite the move away from relying on intuition and introspection in the history of psychology, it still has a role to play.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we've, by and large, gravitated towards behavioral experiments that get increasingly sophisticated.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: to try to reverse engineer what's going on inside the black box.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When it comes to LLMs, partly because that's so different from us, relying exclusively on behavior is even more difficult because we have even less of an idea of what might be going on inside the black box.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and we have reasons to think it might be very different.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I think we both agree that we have to supplement this with mechanistic work that essentially involve performing causal interventions on the inner mechanisms, on the inner workings of the systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So decoding representation and computations that the systems that are in principle available to the systems and then intervening on them to confirm hypotheses about the causal role of these representations and computations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we have methods to do that, and partly
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Why we can be a little optimistic about this project, even though it's extremely challenging, especially to be scaled up to large models, is because unlike what's happening in neuroscience with the brain, where the range of decoding methods and intervention methods we have is extremely limited, but for ethical and for simply practical reasons, we just don't have ground truth access to activation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: we also are generally unable to make specific interventions on activations in the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When it comes to LLAMS, we have full ground truth knowledge of all activations of every single part of the network.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we also have full access to all of it for interventions at inference time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that opens up a whole new range of things we can do.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that enables us to go beyond behavioral studies and actually decode these features
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: philosophers would generally put it, representations and computations that the system is actually making use of, and try to reverse engineer what kind of algorithms it's making use of.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So part of the broader problem projects that we have with Charles is to, suppose that we start with these investigative kinds, as we put, as Adivald calls them, these human-centered capacities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We can operationalize them and do behavioral experiments in the top down.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then from bottom up, we can also try to reverse engineer the mechanics of building blocks of the computations and representations that elements make use of to solve the task related to that particular capacity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then we can meet somewhere in the middle and try to, from that line of work that I
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: these things from both ends bring to the fore some kinds of mid-level abstractions as we call it or computational building blocks that might be key to the performance of the system in that domain so for example if you're interested in the capacity for reasoning you can start with this very broad
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: human-centric notion of reasoning, then try to operationalize it in a reasoning task, then do some behavioral testing and then mechanistic interpretability of that reasoning task, find out how the system is solving it, find out how the other one is doing
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: well and why reverse engineer building blocks that might for example have to be variable manipulation viable binding and then from there you might be able to iteratively refine the notion of reasoning you started with uh to have a more specific and less human centric notion that is now operationalized in more low level
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: multiple terms that involve the manipulation of variables in certain ways and the banning of variables to figures, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So yeah, so that's, I think, the general approach we take.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, does any of that feed back into interactions, how we humans interact with LLMs?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I think that's one way in which it could feed back is simply in terms of challenging our spontaneous anthropomorphic attitudes to LLMs to some extent.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The same way if you read a lot of animal cognition, perhaps you will interact with your cat in a slightly different way that you might maybe not rush to conclude
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that when your cat performs a certain behavior, it has understood what you think and it's modeling what you're thinking about what it's thinking or something.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Perhaps you might adopt a more deflationary attitude to explain the behavior of the cat.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It doesn't mean you have to love them any less, or it doesn't mean you have to, you know,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That is the other thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you want, at the end of the day, to speak to your cat like a human because you're the urban gentleman for that, then that's all the more part of you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In the same way, if you find it useful to treat LLMs in the way you interact with them,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: to have fluid interactions with them, to treat them as if they had beliefs, desires, et cetera, of human-like capacities, then that's fine if that's for actual purposes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But at least if that line of work that we are sketching here ends up maturing enough, the hope is that we can interact with LLMs perhaps in a way that's
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: where even if we have that kind of intentional stance and make believe about the kinds of capacities they have, at the background, we will know what their limitations are and what their actual capacities are.

text: I don't know if you agree with that, Charles, because we're going to discuss that much.

text: Yeah, I agree with all that.

text: I just had a slightly different first reaction to the question.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I took the question to be in part about
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: how to deal with the sort of prompt sensitivity of models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The fact that sometimes we write something that seems natural to us, but provokes an unexpected response from a large language model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And how do we think about that?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the first thought that occurred to me was just that we should distinguish between different kinds of large language models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You know, we have this sort of huge large language models, which are
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: fine-tuned to interact with us in a particular way.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And here's the central point, they're trained on a sort of unthinkably large database, whereas there are other sorts of large language models where the training data is more circumscribed and where we know
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: in more detail where you can survey what the training data says.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I think if you're interested in what the mechanisms are underlying the responses, it's certainly very helpful to look at smaller
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: but nevertheless large language models where the training data is known to us.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Because when you train a model on the entire internet, there are going to be all kinds of subtle signals in there that we don't have much hope of tracing back to their source, but which will influence the model behavior in all sorts of ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But working with these somewhat more conscripted models gets rid of that problem, at least in part.
